writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey stared at his reflection in the mirror, the fluorescent lights of the FBI's New York office overhead making his eyes squint. He adjusted his tie, a habitual gesture that brought back memories of his past life. Who would have thought that the infamous art forger would trade in his paintbrush for a badge? Certainly not the art world, where his forgeries still hung in museums and private collections, masquerading as masterpieces.

As he made his way to the conference room, his mind wandered back to his old partner, Matthew Keller. Their partnership had been a symphony of deception, with Neal as the maestro. They were unstoppable, remember? The thrill of the heist, the art of deception itself, had been their game. But at what cost?

Keller's voice cut through his reverie, echoing in his mind. "We've got a new score, Neal. One that'll make our past heists look like amateur hour." The excitement in his voice was palpable, but Neal's gut twisted with unease.

He entered the conference room, where Keller was already seated, a sly grin spreading across his face. "Neal, my friend, you look like you've lost your last marble."

Neal took a seat, his eyes scanning the room. "What's the plan, Matthew?"

Keller's grin grew wider. "We're going to steal the famous 'Lady in Red' painting. It's a masterpiece, and it's going to be a challenge worthy of our skills."

Neal's instincts screamed at him to walk away, but his curiosity got the better of him. "Why this painting? What's so special about it?"

Keller leaned forward, his eyes gleaming. "It's not just any painting, Neal. It's a chance to prove ourselves, to show the world we're still the best. And, of course, the payday is substantial."

Neal's doubts crept to the surface. This didn't feel right. The thrill of the heist, the art of deception, had always been about the challenge, the rush of adrenaline. But now, as he looked at Keller, he wondered if it was ever about the art itself or just the art of deception.

"Matthew, I don't know if I'm in," Neal said, the words feeling foreign on his lips.

Keller's grin faltered, and for a moment, Neal saw a glimmer of the old Matthew, the one he had partnered with all those years ago. "What's gotten into you, Neal? You're not going soft on me, are you?"

Neal shook his head, trying to clear the cobwebs. "I'm just...hesitant. This doesn't feel right."

Keller's expression turned cold, and Neal realized he was looking at a stranger. "You're not hesitating, Neal. You're stalling. You're wondering if you've really changed or if you're just fooling yourself."

The words struck a chord deep within Neal. Can a wolf ever truly become a sheep, or is it just wearing a wool coat? He thought about his work with the FBI, the satisfaction he felt when justice was served. It was a different kind of thrill, one that didn't involve deception or theft.

"I think I've changed, Matthew," Neal said, his voice firm. "I'm not the same person I was when we were partners."

Keller's laughter was like a slap in the face. "You'll always be the same, Neal. You're just wearing a badge now. That's all."

The words stung, but Neal knew they weren't true. He had grown, evolved. He had found a new purpose, one that didn't involve hurting others.

As he stood up, Keller's eyes narrowed. "You're making a mistake, Neal. You're walking away from the biggest score of your life."

Neal smiled, a sense of clarity washing over him. "I'm not walking away from the score, Matthew. I'm walking away from the past."

With that, Neal turned his back on his old life and walked out of the conference room, leaving Keller and the Lady in Red behind.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
He never thought he'd see Dean Winchester again, let alone feel this strange pull towards him. Crowley's eyes narrowed as he watched Dean saunter into the dimly lit bar, a whiskey already in hand. It had been years since their last encounter, and Crowley had long since convinced himself that their complicated past was just that – past.

But as Dean's gaze met his, a spark of recognition flashed, and Crowley's carefully constructed walls began to crumble. He raised an eyebrow, feigning nonchalance, but his mind was racing. What was Dean doing here? And why did he still look so... tantalizing?

As Dean approached, a charming smile spreading across his face, Crowley's internal monologue turned sarcastic. Oh, this should be good. He tells himself it's just a phase, but deep down, he knows it's more. The demon in him stirred, intrigued by the prospect of rekindling their complicated history.

The conversation flowed easily, like no time had passed at all. They laughed, exchanged witty banter, and Crowley found himself relaxing in Dean's presence. It was as if the years apart had never happened. Almost.

As the night wore on, the bar emptied, and they stumbled into the cool night air, Crowley's thoughts turned introspective. Maybe, just maybe, this was the change he needed. A chance to rewrite the plan, to explore the what-ifs he'd long suppressed.

Dean's voice cut through his reverie, "Hey, want to grab some coffee? I've got a lot to catch you up on." Crowley raised an eyebrow, but his curiosity got the better of him. "What's the worst that could happen?" he said with a smirk, falling into step beside Dean.

Their late-night coffee turned into a midnight stroll, which eventually led to a rooftop confession. Crowley's words spilled out in a rush, secrets and fears he'd kept hidden for so long. Dean listened, his eyes locked on Crowley's, and for the first time in centuries, Crowley felt truly heard.

The night air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers as Dean's lips brushed against his. It was a gentle, exploratory kiss, but it sent shivers down Crowley's spine. He deepened the kiss, his heart pounding in his chest.

The days that followed were a whirlwind of federal agents, family barbecues, and stolen moments whenever they could find them. Crowley found himself attending family gatherings, flipping burgers alongside Dean's family, and laughing at their teasing. Who knew I'd be flipping burgers instead of souls? he quipped, earning a chuckle from Dean.

As they sat on the couch, watching the sunset, Dean turned to him and said, "I never stopped thinking about you, Crowley. You were always the one who got away." Crowley's heart swelled, and he reached out, his fingers intertwining with Dean's.

Their relationship was far from conventional, but as they navigated the complexities of hunters, demons, and federal agents, Crowley realized that some things were worth rewriting the plan for. He glanced at Dean, a smile spreading across his face. Maybe, just maybe, this was the life he was meant to have.

The smell of grilled meat mingled with laughter, a stark contrast to the life Crowley once knew. He leaned into Dean, feeling the warmth of his body, and the demon in him whispered, This is home.

As they walked hand in hand, Crowley couldn't help but wonder what the future held. One thing was certain, though – he was ready to face it, as long as Dean was by his side.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
I stared at the stack of files in front of me, trying to make sense of the tangled web of deceit and corruption that had brought us to this point. The case was a mess, with more twists and turns than a carnival funhouse. But as I began to speak, something unexpected happened.

"I don't think we can just barge in there without a warrant," I said, feeling a strange sense of unease as the words left my lips.

My handler, Peter, raised an eyebrow. "Really, Neal? You're quoting the rulebook now?"

I shrugged, trying to brush it off. "Hey, I'm just saying, we need to do this by the book. We can't just make up our own rules as we go along."

Peter chuckled, a low, rumbling sound. "Never thought I'd see the day you'd be defending proper legal procedures, Caffrey. You're like a born-again bureaucrat."

I shot him a look, but couldn't help the small smile that played on my lips. "Hey, I'm just trying to do the right thing here. You're the one who's always on my case about following the rules."

Peter snorted. "That's because I'm the one who has to clean up after you when you decide to take a shortcut. But I have to admit, it's kind of cute when you try to be a good boy."

I rolled my eyes, feeling a familiar sense of frustration. "I'm not trying to be a good boy, Peter. I'm just trying to get the job done."

But as we continued to discuss the case, I found myself defending the rules again and again. It was like I had suddenly developed a newfound respect for the law, and it was driving Peter crazy.

"I used to think loopholes were my best friends," I said, shaking my head in amazement. "Now I'm patching them up like a pro."

Peter laughed, a full-throated sound this time. "You're like a recovering addict, Neal. 'Hi, my name is Neal Caffrey, and I'm a rule-follower'."

I shot him a look, but couldn't help laughing along with him. It was true, I had come a long way from my days as a con artist. But as I looked at Peter, I realized that it wasn't just about following the rules – it was about trust.

Peter trusted me, despite my past, despite my tendencies to bend the rules. And I trusted him, to have my back, to keep me in line.

As we left the conference room, Peter clapped me on the back. "You know, Neal, I think you're starting to get the hang of this whole 'being a good guy' thing."

I smiled, feeling a strange sense of pride. "Yeah, yeah, I know the drill."

But as we walked out of the building, I felt a strange tingling sensation in my fingers. It was a feeling I'd grown accustomed to over the past few months – the feeling of speaking the truth.

It was a small thing, but it was a start. And as I looked at Peter, I knew that I had finally found a place where I belonged – not as a con artist, but as a consultant, as a partner, as a friend.

"You know, Peter," I said, as we walked down the street. "I think I'm starting to like this whole 'being a good guy' thing."

Peter raised an eyebrow. "Oh? And what brought about this sudden change of heart?"

I shrugged, feeling a small smile play on my lips. "I don't know. Maybe it's just the fact that I'm finally doing something that feels right."

Peter nodded, a small smile on his face. "I think it's more than that, Neal. I think you're just starting to realize that you're not alone."

And as we walked off into the sunset, I knew that he was right. I wasn't alone, not anymore. I had Peter, and I had the law – and together, we were going to make a difference.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
As the silence of space enveloped the starship, Chief Engineer Montgomery Scott's mind was abuzz with the cacophony of his own thoughts. "What in the name of all that's holy has gone wrong?" he muttered to himself, staring at the bank of darkened consoles in front of him. The ship's engines, once purring smoothly, now lay still, refusing to yield even a spark of life.

Scott's frustration was matched only by his determination. He knew there was a solution, hidden in the labyrinth of circuits and wires, if only he could see it. He rubbed his temples, trying to massage away the tension. "Come on, Scotty, think this through," he encouraged himself, recalling the countless times he'd coaxed the Enterprise's engines back to life.

"Captain, I'm afraid I've got nothing," he reported, his voice laced with a mix of apology and frustration, as Captain Kirk and the rest of the senior officers gathered around him.

Kirk's eyes narrowed. "Nothing? Scotty, we need something. We can't just sit here, waiting for...whatever it is that's going to happen next."

Scott nodded, feeling the weight of responsibility settle onto his shoulders. "Aye, sir. I know. But I've tried every diagnostic, every trick in the book. There's no indication of what's causing this failure."

Dr. McCoy, ever the pragmatist, spoke up, "Maybe we're looking at this from the wrong angle. Maybe it's not a mechanical failure at all."

Scott's eyes lit up. "You think it might be something more...exotic, Doctor?"

McCoy shrugged. "I'm just saying, we should consider all possibilities. We're not exactly in a position to rule anything out."

The conversation was interrupted by the sound of Lieutenant Uhura's voice, her words laced with a hint of excitement. "Captain, I'm picking up a strange energy reading from the ship's core."

Scott's ears perked up. "That's it, lass! That's the break we need!" He strode over to Uhura's station, his eyes scanning the data streaming across her console.

As they pored over the readings, the tension in the room began to dissipate, replaced by a sense of hope. Scott's thoughts turned to his mentor, the venerable Engineer's Guildmaster, who had once told him, "Every problem has a solution, you just have to find the right angle."

The memory sparked an idea. "I've got it!" Scott exclaimed, his eyes locking onto a peculiar pattern in the energy signature. "It's not a mechanical failure at all – it's a resonance cascade! The ship's core is generating a harmonic frequency that's cancelling out the engine's power output!"

Kirk's face lit up with a mixture of relief and curiosity. "Can you reverse it, Scotty?"

Scott nodded, already racing toward the solution. "Aye, sir! I can try. But I'll need Lieutenant Spock's help to—"

Spock, ever the logical one, was already by Scott's side, his eyes fixed intently on the data. "Fascinating, Mr. Scott. I believe I can assist in recalibrating the core's frequency."

As the two of them set to work, the rest of the crew watched, a sense of camaraderie and shared purpose filling the air. They'd faced countless challenges together, and this was just another puzzle to solve.

In the silence of space, the Enterprise's crew found a sense of unity, their differences forgotten in the face of adversity. Scott smiled to himself, thinking, In the vastness of space, it's our differences that unite us.

With a final burst of energy, the engines roared back to life, the ship shuddering as power surged through its systems. Scott let out a triumphant whoop, pumping his fist in the air.

Kirk grinned, clapping him on the back. "Well done, Scotty. You've done it again."

Scott chuckled, feeling the familiar glow of pride and satisfaction. "Just another day's work, Captain."

As the Enterprise leapt back into the unknown, its crew stood together, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead, their bond stronger than any starship engine.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
It's ironic, really, being accused of something I didn't do. But then again, irony seems to be my constant companion. I've spent years perfecting the art of deception, only to be suspected of a forgery I had nothing to do with. The universe has a wicked sense of humor.

I watched as Agent Thompson stormed into the office, a look of determination etched on her face. Peter, ever the consummate professional, greeted her with a firm handshake and a charming smile. I, on the other hand, opted for a more...diplomatic approach. I flashed her my most disarming smile, the one that had talked me out of more sticky situations than I care to admit.

"Agent Thompson, what can we do for you?" Peter asked, his tone neutral.

"I'm here to audit your team, Agent Burke," she replied, her eyes scanning the room until they landed on me. "Specifically, I'm looking into a forgery case that suggests Mr. Caffrey's involvement."

I raised an eyebrow, intrigued despite myself. "A forgery, you say? How...amusing."

Thompson's gaze narrowed. "I'm afraid it's no laughing matter, Mr. Caffrey. The evidence points to your...particular set of skills."

I chuckled, a low, smooth sound. "If I were guilty, you'd never know. But lucky for you, I'm not."

Peter cleared his throat, intervening before things escalated. "Agent Thompson, I assure you, Neal is cooperating fully. We'll provide any assistance you need."

Thompson's expression remained skeptical, but she nodded curtly. "Very well. I'll need to review your files, interview your team members...and, of course, speak with Mr. Caffrey at length."

I grinned, a plan already forming in my mind. "I'm at your disposal, Agent Thompson. Fire away."

As Thompson began her audit, I made a mental note to "accidentally" leave a few...creative hints in my wake. A whispered conversation with Mozzie, a strategically placed folder, and a well-timed "coincidence" later, Thompson was hot on the trail of a cleverly constructed red herring.

Meanwhile, I cornered Peter in the break room, a cup of coffee in hand. "Peter, you know I didn't do it. But proving it? That's the tricky part."

Peter raised an eyebrow. "What have you got cooking in that brilliant mind of yours, Neal?"

I smiled, a mischievous glint in my eye. "Let's just say I'm going to give Agent Thompson a show she'll never forget. Trust me, I've got this. Well, mostly."

Peter sighed, a mixture of amusement and exasperation. "Remember when you pulled that stunt in Chicago? This feels like that, but with higher stakes."

I chuckled, recalling the incident. "Ah, yes. The art of misdirection. I've honed my skills since then, Peter. This time, it's not just about me; it's about protecting you and the team."

As the audit continued, Thompson grew increasingly frustrated, her theories thwarted at every turn. I, on the other hand, was in my element, weaving a complex web of deceit and misdirection. It was a delicate balancing act, but I'd danced on the edge before. This time, the stakes were personal.

In the end, it was a cleverly planted piece of evidence that cracked the case – a forgery within a forgery, if you will. Thompson's eyes widened as the truth dawned on her: the real culprit was not me, but a disgruntled former employee with a grudge against the team.

As the dust settled, Thompson turned to me, a begrudging respect in her eyes. "Neal Caffrey, you're a formidable opponent. I'll give you that."

I smiled, relieved that my plan had worked. "Elementary, my dear Agent Thompson. Sometimes, the best way to clear your name is to blur the line between clever and reckless."

Peter clapped me on the back, a grin on his face. "Well, that was fun. Mostly."

I laughed, feeling a sense of vindication wash over me. Maybe, just maybe, I'd earned a little bit of trust back. Time to cash in on that currency.
